thread.title: Victory for Theresa May in key Brexit vote as Commons debates continue
thread.title_full: Victory for Theresa May in key Brexit vote as Commons debates continue

author: Jonathan Walker
title: Victory for Theresa May in key Brexit vote as Commons debates continue
text:
News Victory for Theresa May in key Brexit vote as Commons debates continue Newcastle MP calls for North East to have a say on Bexit as PM wins Commons vote during ongoing negotiations Share Prime Minister Theresa May making a statement to MPs following the EU summit in Valletta, Malta (Photo: PA) Share   
Prime Minister Theresa May has won another major Commons vote over Brexit after MPs rejected attempts to force her to deliver regular reports to Parliament about the progress of negotiations with the EU. 
MPs are considering amendments to the European Union (Notification of Withdrawal) Bill, which allows the Prime Minister to trigger Article 50 and begin the process of leaving the EU. 
But in an early sign that the Commons will back the Government’s plans, MPs voted against an amendment proposed by the Labour leadership which would have required Mrs May to deliver a progress report to Parliament every two months. 
MPs threw out the plan by 284 votes in favour to 333 votes against, a majority for the Government’s position of 49. 
Voting on the first set of amendments began at 9pm and MPs then began a debate on a second set of amendments, this time focusing on calls to ensure the devolved administrations in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland are consulted as Brexit negotiations with the EU take place. 
It meant the Commons was set to hold a rare late-night debate. These were once frequent occurrences at Westminster, but have become much rarer since the introduction of “family-friendly” hours in 2003. 
A number of MPs from English constituencies were also set to call for English regions to be consulted. Catherine Mckinnell 
They included Newcastle North MP Catherine McKinnell , who said she was concerned about a promise made by David Davis, the Secretary of State for Exiting the European Union, to consult mayors. 
While Liverpool, Manchester and the Tees Valley area are to elect mayors on May 4, plans for an elected mayor for seven North East councils have fallen through. 
Ms McKinnell said: “We’ve had vague promises from the Government about holding ‘a meeting in York’ for mayors from the north, after elections are held in May. Read More Theresa May urges MPs to back Brexit as historic Bill returns to Commons 
“But what about those areas – like the North East – that won’t have an elected mayor at that point? Are we going to be excluded from this process, despite the huge impact leaving the EU – and particularly the Single Market – will have on our region? 
“And surely any such discussions need to start well before May, given the tight two-year negotiating timescale the Government is facing. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
